logical_representation: IF work_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> CASE project_location: 'Fort McMurray' -> ALLOWANCE(200.00), 'Grande Prairie' -> ALLOWANCE(205.00), 'Athabasca' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Bonnyville' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Calgary' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Camrose' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Caroline' -> ALLOWANCE(125.00), 'Canmore/Exshaw' -> ALLOWANCE(195.00), 'Cold Lake' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Drumheller' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Edmonton' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Edson' -> ALLOWANCE(175.00), 'Forestburg' -> ALLOWANCE(130.00), 'Fox Creek' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Grande Cache' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Hanna' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Hardisty/Wainwright' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'High Level' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Hinton' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Lethbridge' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Lloydminster' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Medicine Hat' -> ALLOWANCE(170.00), 'Peace River' -> ALLOWANCE(185.00), 'Pincher Creek/Waterton' -> ALLOWANCE(160.00), 'Red Deer' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Rocky Mountain House' -> ALLOWANCE(190.00), 'Stettler' -> ALLOWANCE(190.00), 'Swan Hills' -> ALLOWANCE(150.00), 'Valley View' -> ALLOWANCE(165.00), 'Vermillion' -> ALLOWANCE(180.00), 'Wabasca' -> ALLOWANCE(200.00), 'Whitecourt' -> ALLOWANCE(155.00) ELSE ALLOWANCE(150.00)
reasoning: This rule provides a list of exceptions to the standard subsistence rate based on geographic location, which is a core function of subsistence allowance policies.

name: Review of Subsistence Amounts
rule_text: These amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The subsistence allowance rates will be reviewed by a joint committee if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_change == true -> TRIGGER_REVIEW(subsistence_amounts)
reasoning: This rule governs the process for updating subsistence allowances, an administrative component of the policy.

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Sites (>475km)
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 or more radius kilometers away, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just for days worked.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km >= 475 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall >= 475 -> APPLY_ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE, 7_DAYS_PER_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule modifies the payment schedule for subsistence based on extreme distance, directly impacting how the allowance is calculated and paid.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture and Waiver
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: An employee will lose their subsistence allowance if they are absent, but this can be waived if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF employee_absent == true AND is_absence_preauthorized == false -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (absenteeism) under which an employee loses their entitlement to the subsistence allowance, making it a key rule for allowance administration.

name: Additional Subsistence Day for Travel
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations. This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (e.g., receipt or registration verification).
summary: Non-local employees on subsistence projects over 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence for either the day before starting or the day after finishing work, provided they show proof of accommodation.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == false AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 200 AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_ACCOMMODATION' -> PAY(1_DAY_SUBSISTENCE_ON_TRAVEL_DAY)
reasoning: This rule provides an additional monetary benefit related to travel for subsistence projects, directly falling under the scope of subsistence allowances.

name: Airfare as Travel Allowance Alternative
rule_text: or actual airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: Instead of the standard distance-based travel allowance, an employee can be reimbursed for the actual cost of their airfare if they provide proof of air travel.
logical_representation: IF travel_mode == 'AIR' AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_AIRFARE' -> PAY(ACTUAL_AIRFARE)
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative calculation method for the travel allowance, which is a key part of subsistence and travel policies.

name: Fort McMurray Initial and Terminal Travel Rate
rule_text: Initial and Terminal travel for any project which falls within one- hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall will be two hundred and ninety-seven dollars ($297.00).
summary: For any project within a 100km radius of Fort McMurray city hall, the initial and terminal travel allowance is a flat rate of $297.00.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' AND job_location_radius_km <= 100 -> PAY(297.00_FOR_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific travel allowance for a particular geographic area, making it a location-based subsistence rule.

name: No Travel Allowance with Client-Provided Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no travel allowance will be paid to the employee.
logical_representation: IF client_provided_transport == true -> FORFEIT(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition under which the travel allowance entitlement is nullified, directly impacting subsistence payments.

name: Initial/Terminal Travel for Very Remote Projects (>475km)
rule_text: On jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial and terminal travel amounts will be mutually agreed between the Local Lodge and the Employer to a maximum of four hundred and fifty-five dollars ($455.00) each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: For jobs more than 475km away, initial and terminal travel pay is mutually agreed upon, up to a maximum of $455.00 each way, or the actual cost of airfare with proof.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 475 -> PAY(MUTUALLY_AGREED_AMOUNT) WITH MAX(455.00_EACH_WAY) OR (IF travel_mode == 'AIR' AND claim_type == 'PROOF_OF_AIRFARE' -> PAY(ACTUAL_AIRFARE))
reasoning: This rule defines the travel allowance calculation for projects at extreme distances, a key part of a comprehensive subsistence policy.

name: Review of Initial and Terminal Travel Amounts
rule_text: Initial and terminal travel amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The initial and terminal travel allowance rates will be reviewed by a joint committee if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_change == true -> TRIGGER_REVIEW(initial_terminal_travel_amounts)
reasoning: This rule governs the process for updating initial and terminal travel allowances, which is an administrative aspect of subsistence policies.

name: Initial Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay- off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid out after an employee has been on the job for 15 calendar days, or at layoff if it occurs sooner.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job >= 15 OR employee_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(INITIAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule dictates the timing and conditions for paying the travel allowance, which is an administrative aspect of subsistence benefits.

name: Terminal Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The terminal travel allowance is paid when the employee is laid off.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(TERMINAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule specifies the event that triggers the payment of the terminal travel allowance, an administrative component of subsistence policies.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Pay on Quit or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before their travel allowance is paid, they forfeit any right to that payment.
logical_representation: IF employee_status IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED_FOR_CAUSE'] -> FORFEIT(OUTSTANDING_TRAVEL_PAYMENTS)
reasoning: This rule outlines conditions for forfeiture of the travel allowance based on employment status, directly affecting the payment of subsistence benefits.

name: Documentation for Subsistence Qualification
rule_text: To qualify for the subsistence allowance under Article 16.01, the member, will supply two (2) of the following documents as verification of their name and current address. It is understood that the Employer will ensure any copies of such documents will be handled in accordance with PIPA regulations. - Any government issued identification - Utility Bill - Bank Statement - Vehicle Registration - Housing Rental Agreement - Mortgage Documentation - Land Title - Credit Card Statement - Income Tax Assessment - Property Tax Assessment - Employment Insurance
summary: To qualify for subsistence, an employee must provide two forms of identification from an approved list (such as government ID, utility bill, or bank statement) to verify their name and current address.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == 'SUBSISTENCE_QUALIFICATION' -> REQUIRE(2_DOCUMENTS_FOR_ID_AND_ADDRESS_VERIFICATION)
reasoning: This rule sets a procedural requirement for an employee to become eligible for subsistence, making it a foundational rule for the allowance.

name: Ineligibility of Local Residents for Subsistence Benefits
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel
summary: On a project designated for subsistence, employees who already live in the project area are not eligible for the accommodation allowance or initial/terminal travel pay.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true -> INELIGIBLE_FOR(ACCOMMODATION_ALLOWANCE, INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule defines an exclusion criterion for subsistence benefits based on an employee's residency, which is a fundamental aspect of subsistence policies.

name: Daily Travel for Local Residents on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 16.01 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: Local residents on a subsistence project who live more than 45km from the project site are not eligible for accommodation allowance but are entitled to receive daily travel payments.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true AND distance_from_residence_to_project_km > 45 -> ELIGIBLE_FOR(DAILY_TRAVEL_PAYMENT)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific travel benefit for a subset of employees (local residents) under certain conditions, making it a subsistence-related rule.

name: Daily Travel for Non-Local Residents on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the free zone to the temporary domicile and return.
summary: On a subsistence project, non-local employees whose temporary lodging is more than 45km from the job site will either be given transportation to the job or paid $0.69 per km for travel from their temporary lodging to the job and back.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == false AND distance_from_temp_domicile_to_project_km > 45 AND work_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION) OR PAY(0.69 * travel_distance_from_free_zone_km * 2)
reasoning: This rule describes a daily travel benefit specifically for non-local employees on a subsistence project, which is a core component of subsistence and remote work allowances.

name: Fort McMurray Transport for Subsistence Employees
rule_text: In Ft. McMurray, subsistence employees will be provided transportation to and from the job site as per current arrangements under the Agreement.
summary: In Fort McMurray, employees receiving subsistence will be provided with transportation to and from the job site according to the agreement's current arrangements.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule outlines a location-specific transportation benefit for subsistence employees, making it a key rule within the subsistence allowance topic.

name: Pay Period Holdback Limit
rule_text: In no case shall more than five (5) regular working days be held back in any one payroll period.
summary: An employer is not permitted to hold back more than five regular working days' worth of pay from an employee in any single payroll period.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(pay_holdback_days (llm) <= 5)
reasoning: This rule sets a maximum limit on the delay between work performed and its payment, directly governing the administration of labor compensation.

name: Final Pay on Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or discharged from the service of the Employer shall receive their wages and all monies owing and their Employment Insurance Contribution Certificate.
summary: Upon being laid off or discharged, an employee must receive all outstanding wages and any other money owed, along with their Employment Insurance documentation.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> PROVIDE(FINAL_PAY) AND PROVIDE(EI_CERTIFICATE)
reasoning: This rule outlines the employer's obligation to provide final compensation and required documentation when employment is terminated, which is a final settlement for labor worked.

name: Termination Slip Requirement
rule_text: the employee shall receive an Employer termination slip which shall show either their net pay and deductions, or the basic factors from which their pay will be calculated including: total pay hours, travel allowance and transportation allowances, subsistence, etc.
summary: When laid off or discharged, an employee must be given a termination slip that details the calculation of their final pay, including hours, allowances, and deductions.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> PROVIDE(TERMINATION_SLIP_WITH_PAY_DETAILS)
reasoning: This rule pertains to the procedural and informational requirements of final pay, which is an administrative component of labor compensation.

name: Payment Method by Direct Deposit
rule_text: Pay shall be by direct deposit.
summary: All payments to employees must be made via direct deposit.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(PAYMENT_METHOD = 'DIRECT_DEPOSIT')
reasoning: This rule specifies the mandatory method for delivering compensation for labor.

name: Final Pay Timing for Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: and the Employer shall direct deposit monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday, and Recognized Holidays.
summary: For an employee who is laid off or discharged, the employer must issue final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment (ROE) by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] -> CONSTRAINT(FINAL_PAY_DUE_DATE <= 'next_regular_pay_period')
reasoning: This rule establishes the deadline for issuing final payment upon termination, a critical part of the labor compensation process.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty for Layoff or Discharge
rule_text: Should the Employer fail to comply with this provision (excluding the reference to the Record of Employment), the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates for each day they are kept waiting exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of pay.
summary: If an employer is late providing final pay to a laid off or discharged employee, they must pay a penalty of 8 hours of straight-time pay for each business day the payment is delayed, up to a maximum of 40 hours.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'DISCHARGED'] AND is_final_pay_late (llm) == true -> PAY(PENALTY, 8_HOURS_ST * final_pay_delay_days (llm), MAX=40_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule specifies a financial penalty for failing to meet the final payment deadline, directly impacting the total compensation for worked time.

name: Final Pay Timing for Quit
rule_text: When an employee quits of their own volition, the Employer shall direct deposit all monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Recognized Holidays.
summary: When an employee resigns, the employer must issue their final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment (ROE) by the next regular payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' -> CONSTRAINT(FINAL_PAY_DUE_DATE <= 'next_regular_pay_period')
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final compensation when an employee quits, which is a key part of the labor payment process.

name: Late Final Pay Penalty for Quit
rule_text: If the Employer fails to comply with this requirement within five (5) working days after the specified pay day, the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates.
summary: If an employer is more than five working days late in issuing final pay to an employee who has quit, the employee is entitled to a penalty payment of 8 hours at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND final_pay_delay_days (llm) > 5 -> PAY(PENALTY, 8_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for late final payment to a resigned employee, impacting the total compensation for their worked time.

name: Pay Shortage Correction Timeline
rule_text: If on an employee's weekly paycheck, they are shorted pay, the employee is required to notify the Employer immediately in writing. The Employer shall provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and Recognized Holidays after receiving the notification of the shortage in writing.
summary: If an employee's pay is short, they must notify the employer in writing. The employer then has 10 business days from the date of receiving the notification to correct the shortage on a future paycheck.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_notification_received (llm) == true -> CONSTRAINT(PAY_ADJUSTMENT_DUE_DAYS = 10)
reasoning: This rule establishes the procedure and deadline for correcting payment errors, ensuring accurate compensation for labor.

name: Penalty for Late Pay Shortage Correction
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Employer will pay one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day the employee is kept waiting from the date the notification of shortage was received in writing by the Employer to a maximum of seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
summary: If an employer fails to correct a pay shortage within the 10-day window, they must pay a penalty of $100 per day of delay, starting from the notification date, up to a $700 maximum.
logical_representation: IF pay_adjustment_delay_days (llm) > 10 -> PAY(PENALTY, $100 * (pay_adjustment_delay_days (llm)), MAX=$700)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to correct pay errors in a timely manner, which directly relates to ensuring proper compensation for worked time.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a results of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -in-Law, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Eligible employees can receive bereavement pay for up to three days of lost work to attend a funeral or memorial service for a specified family member. The pay is 8 hours per day at the employee's straight-time base rate.
logical_representation: IF deceased_relation (llm) IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] AND bereavement_leave_reason (llm) == 'ATTEND_FUNERAL_OR_MEMORIAL' -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * bereavement_days_taken (llm), MAX_DAYS=3)
reasoning: This rule specifies the amount, duration, and qualifying reasons for paid bereavement leave, which is a direct component of labor compensation rules.

name: Reporting Pay, Inclement Weather (Work Not Started)
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee reports to a job site but cannot start work due to bad weather, they are guaranteed two hours of pay. They are required to stay on site for this two-hour period unless a supervisor permits them to leave.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status (Unsupported) == 'NOT_STARTED' AND weather_condition (llm) == 'INCLEMENT' -> PAY(2_HOURS_ST) AND REQUIRE(REMAIN_ON_SITE(2_HOURS))
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment for showing up to work when work cannot begin due to weather. This is a form of guaranteed time/pay, which falls under the category of how labor time is compensated.

name: Reporting Pay, Work Not Available
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and is not given the opportunity to work because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day's work, they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: If an employee shows up for their shift and there is no work available, and they were not notified of this the previous day, they will receive two hours of pay and can leave the job site immediately.
logical_representation: IF work_availability (llm) == 'NOT_AVAILABLE' AND prior_day_notification (llm) == false -> PAY(2_HOURS_ST) AND ALLOW(LEAVE_SITE_IMMEDIATELY)
reasoning: This rule defines the compensation (reporting time) an employee is entitled to when they report for duty but no work is available. This is a minimum pay guarantee, which is a core component of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Subsistence Receipt Date Requirement
rule_text: 1. Date
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the date of the transaction.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_date (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies a mandatory piece of information (date) required on a receipt for subsistence reimbursement, which is a condition for receiving the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt Establishment and Contact Person
rule_text: 2. Name of Establishment and Name of Contact Person if appropriate (see examples below) ABC Motel -Company letterhead receipt -Name of Contact Person not required B & B or Relative (non-registered) -Name of Contact Person required
summary: For subsistence reimbursement, the receipt must include the name of the establishment. It must also include a contact person's name if the accommodation is from a non-registered provider (e.g., B&B, relative), but this is not required for registered establishments (e.g., motel).
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_establishment_name (llm) == true) AND IF establishment_is_registered (llm) == false -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_contact_person (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies two distinct but related pieces of information required on a subsistence receipt: the establishment name (always required) and a contact person (conditionally required), both of which are prerequisites for the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt Address and Phone Number Requirement
rule_text: 3. Complete Address and Phone Number of the Establishment
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must include the complete address and phone number of the establishment.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_address_and_phone (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule mandates that a receipt for subsistence must contain the establishment's contact details, which is a condition for reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Employee Name Requirement
rule_text: 4. Employee's Full Name
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the employee's full name.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_employee_name (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule requires the employee's name on the receipt for a subsistence claim, a necessary condition for validating and processing the reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Reason for Cost Requirement
rule_text: 5. Reason/Description of Cost (including dates)
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must describe the reason for the cost and include the relevant dates.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_cost_reason (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule mandates a description of the cost on the subsistence receipt, which is a condition for claim validation and reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt Total Cost Requirement
rule_text: 6. Total Cost
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must show the total cost paid.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> REQUIRE(receipt_has_total_cost (llm) == true)
reasoning: This rule specifies that the total cost must be on the subsistence receipt, a fundamental requirement for processing the reimbursement.

name: Invalidity of Incomplete Subsistence Receipts
rule_text: A receipt without complete or required information will not be considered.
summary: A receipt for subsistence reimbursement that is missing any of the required information will be rejected and not considered for payment.
logical_representation: IF claim_type (Unsupported) == 'SUBSISTENCE' AND receipt_is_complete (llm) == false -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE('SUBSISTENCE'))
reasoning: This rule defines the consequence of failing to meet the documentation requirements for subsistence, directly impacting the allowance entitlement. It serves as the enforcement clause for all preceding receipt requirements.

name: EDO Entitlement, Annual
rule_text: With the understanding that this work schedule is utilized to compensate the employees for hours lost during the twenty-six (26) yearly earned days off (EDO's)...
summary: Employees on the Compressed Work Week are entitled to 26 Earned Days Off (EDOs) per year, which is compensated for by the 45-hour work week.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> PROVIDE(earned_days_off_entitlement (llm) = 26_per_year)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to a specific number of paid days off, which is a core component of time and compensation.

name: EDO Scheduling, Scheduled vs Flex
rule_text: Of the twentysix (26) EDO's, eighteen (18) will be scheduled by Suncor and the remaining eight (8) will be designated as flex EDO's to be taken as mutually agreed between the employee and the supervisor.
summary: Of the 26 annual Earned Days Off, 18 are scheduled by Suncor and 8 are flexible EDOs scheduled by mutual agreement between the employee and supervisor.
logical_representation: SET(earned_day_off_type (llm) = 'SCHEDULED', count=18) AND SET(earned_day_off_type (llm) = 'FLEX', count=8)
reasoning: This rule outlines the process and responsibility for scheduling time off, which affects labor planning and pay.

name: Long Term Base Crew, Definition
rule_text: It is understood that when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew employee.
summary: An employee is considered "Long Term Base Crew" and automatically placed on the Compressed Work Week schedule if they are hired with the expectation of working for more than six weeks.
logical_representation: IF expected_employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW') AND APPLY_PAY_RULES('CWW')
reasoning: This rule defines a specific class of employee, which is a condition for several other pay and scheduling rules.

name: Employee Transition, Short to Long Term
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms (except as outlined in item (e) below).
summary: If a short-term employee works for more than six weeks, they are reclassified as Long Term Crew and paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules, unless it's a Plant Shutdown.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'SHORT_TERM' AND employment_duration_weeks (llm) > 6 AND event (Unsupported) != 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW')
reasoning: This rule defines a change in employee status based on tenure, which directly impacts their pay and scheduling rules.

name: Termination Pay Adjustment, Unused Flex EDO
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: Upon termination, if a long-term employee has not taken a flex EDO in the preceding six weeks, any regular hours they worked beyond 240 during that period will be paid out at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' AND employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND flex_edo_taken_in_lookback (llm) == false AND lookback_period_weeks (llm) == 6 -> PAY(hours_in_excess_of(240, regular_hours_in_lookback (llm)), OT_RATE)
reasoning: This is a specific pay calculation rule triggered by termination and tied to the usage of banked earned time off.

name: Flex EDO, Employee Notice Requirement
rule_text: The employee will provide a minimum of seven (7) days notice when requesting flex. EDO's. Special circumstances will be considered by the supervisor wherein a shorter notice period may be allowed.
summary: Employees must give at least seven days' notice when requesting a flex EDO, though supervisors may approve requests with shorter notice in special cases.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: Employee request for flex EDO requires MIN(7_days_notice) unless supervisor approves exception.
reasoning: This is a procedural rule governing how employees can use their entitled time off, which affects scheduling and labor management.

name: Flex EDO Payout, Forfeiture
rule_text: ...and that overtime payment will not be made for flex days not taken by the employee with the exception of those circumstances outlined in items b) and c) above
summary: Employees will not be paid out for unused flex EDOs, except under specific circumstances such as early termination or termination without having taken a recent flex day.
logical_representation: IF NOT (employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED' AND (termination_condition_b (llm) == true OR termination_condition_c (llm) == true)) -> FORFEIT(PAY_FOR_UNUSED_FLEX_EDO)
reasoning: This rule establishes a 'use it or lose it' policy for an entitlement, with specific exceptions, which is a core compensation rule.

name: Plant Shutdown Employment Term, Short Term Hires
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than six (6) weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a Plant Shutdown will remain classified as short-term employees for pay purposes for the entire duration of the shutdown, even if it exceeds six weeks.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' AND employee_is_hired_for_shutdown (llm) == true -> SET(employee_type (llm) = 'SHORT_TERM') FOR DURATION(event)
reasoning: This rule creates an exception to the standard employee classification transition rule, based on a specific work event, which affects pay calculation.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedule, Long Term Crew
rule_text: All Long Term Base Crew employees shall remain on the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a Plant Shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees continue to be paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules, including overtime for work on scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'PLANT_SHUTDOWN' AND employee_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW' -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('CWW') AND APPLY_PAY_RULES('CLAUSE_C')
reasoning: This rule confirms that the standard pay and overtime rules for a specific employee class are maintained during a special event.

name: Work on Scheduled EDOs
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's will be paid at double (2x).
summary: Any work performed on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) must be paid at double the employee's regular rate.
logical_representation: IF is_edo_day (llm) == true -> PAY(2.0x)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific pay rate (double time) for work on a particular type of day (an EDO), directly related to how labor time is categorized and compensated.

name: Shift Change Notice Penalty
rule_text: An employee will be given twenty-four (24) hours advance notice prior to the start of their new shift and if not then they shall be paid their first shift at time and one-half (1 ½x).
summary: If an employee is not given at least 24 hours' notice before a shift change, their entire first shift on the new schedule must be paid at time-and-a-half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice_hours (llm) < 24 -> PREMIUM(1.5) FOR first_shift
reasoning: This rule imposes a premium pay rate on worked hours as a penalty for insufficient notice, directly altering the calculation of labor cost for that time.

name: EDO Handling on Shift Transfer
rule_text: When an employee is transferred to a different shift schedule all scheduled days off which have been earned must be given to the employee prior to the start of their new schedule. If earned days off are worked they shall be considered overtime and paid the applicable overtime rate.
summary: When an employee is transferred to a new shift, any Earned Days Off (EDOs) they have accrued must be taken before the new schedule starts. If the employee is required to work on these EDOs, the time must be paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TRANSFER' AND is_earned_day_off (llm) == true -> PAY(OT) OR PROVIDE(time_off)
reasoning: This rule dictates how a specific type of time off (EDO) is treated during a change in work status. It mandates that this time is either taken as leave or paid out at a premium rate, both of which are core labor time calculations.

name: Bereavement Pay
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of service with an Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a result of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -inLaw, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Employees with more than three years of service are entitled to up to three days of paid bereavement leave. Each day is paid as 8 hours at the straight-time rate. This applies to the death of an immediate family member.
logical_representation: IF years_of_service (llm) > 3 AND leave_type (llm) == 'BEREAVEMENT' AND relationship (llm) IN ['Spouse', 'Child', 'Parent', 'Parent-in-Law', 'Grandparent', 'Sibling'] -> PAY(8_hours_ST) FOR MAX(3_days)
reasoning: This rule governs payment for time not actively worked but contractually compensable (bereavement leave). This falls under the broader category of labor time management and pay calculation.

name: Vacation Pay Tiers
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, vacation pay is calculated as a percentage of earnings based on years of service, starting at 6% and increasing up to 10% for employees with over 12 years of service.
logical_representation: IF employment_type (llm) == 'Long-Term Maintenance' -> PAY(vacation_rate BASED_ON years_of_service (llm))
reasoning: This rule defines a core component of employee compensation (vacation pay percentage) that is directly tied to their service time. This is a fundamental calculation in overall labor cost.

name: Vacation Pay Service Continuity
rule_text: Long term maintenance employees who have a break in service with the Employer will maintain their years of service should the break in service be less than ninety (90) calendar days. A change to the commercial contract whereby an individual is moved from one Signatory Employer to another shall not be considered a break in service. The break in service is not applicable for those who quit or are terminated.
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, a break in service of less than 90 days does not reset their years of service for vacation pay calculation. Moving between signatory employers is not considered a break. This does not apply to employees who quit or are terminated.
logical_representation: IF employment_type (llm) == 'Long-Term Maintenance' AND break_in_service_days (llm) < 90 AND employee_status (Unsupported) NOT IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED'] -> MAINTAIN(years_of_service (llm))
reasoning: This rule dictates how to calculate an employee's seniority ('years of service'), which is a critical input for other labor rules like vacation pay. It directly affects the rate of pay and entitlements.

name: Maintenance Work Wage Rate
rule_text: Wage rates for maintenance work shall be $0.75 per hour less than base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement of the Member Union where such work is to be performed and shall be paid to all employees under the terms of this agreement.
summary: For maintenance work, the wage rate is set at $0.75 per hour below the base rate specified in the relevant Area Labour Agreement.
logical_representation: IF activity_type (Unsupported) == 'MAINTENANCE' -> PAY(base_rate(base_rate_source (llm)) - $0.75)
reasoning: This rule defines how to calculate the wage rate for a specific type of work, which is a core part of pay calculation for time worked.

name: Electronic Pay Records Option
rule_text: At the Employer's option, electronic pay records and records of Employment may be provided in lieu of  printed  records.
summary: The employer has the option to provide pay records and Records of Employment electronically instead of as printed documents.
logical_representation: EMPLOYER_OPTION(PROVIDE_ELECTRONIC_PAY_RECORDS)
reasoning: This rule pertains to the administration and delivery of pay information, which is ancillary to the calculation of time worked but falls under the general scope of wages and payment processes.

name: Printed Pay Records on Request
rule_text: Upon  request  from  an  employee  that  does  not  have  the  capability  to  access electronic records, printed pay records shall be issued.
summary: If an employee cannot access electronic records, they can request printed pay records, and the employer must provide them.
logical_representation: IF employee_request (llm) == 'PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS' AND access_capability (llm) == 'NONE' -> PROVIDE(PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS)
reasoning: This is a procedural rule about the format and delivery of wage information, which is part of the overall wage process.

name: Printed Record of Employment on Request
rule_text: Upon request, a printed record of employment will be issued.
summary: An employee can request a printed Record of Employment at any time.
logical_representation: IF employee_request (llm) == 'PRINTED_ROE' -> PROVIDE(PRINTED_ROE)
reasoning: This rule governs the administration and format of employment documentation related to wages.

name: Maintenance Wage Rate, Ft. McMurray Area
rule_text: For projects that are located within a one hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall, wage rates for maintenance shall be 100% of base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement.
summary: For maintenance work on projects within a 100km radius of Ft. McMurray city hall, the wage rate is 100% of the base rate from the Area Labour Agreement, overriding the standard reduction.
logical_representation: IF activity_type (Unsupported) == 'MAINTENANCE' AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 100 -> PAY(base_rate(base_rate_source (llm)))
reasoning: This rule provides a location-based exception for calculating the wage rate for maintenance work, directly impacting pay for time worked.

name: Enablement Provision Extension
rule_text: Any enablement provisions made by the Local Unions to the wage rates or benefits  packages and provided to any Employer will be extended to NMA Employers when bidding the same or similar work packages. In these circumstances' maintenance will be at the enabled conditions.
summary: If a Local Union grants concessions on wage rates or benefits to any employer, those same concessions must be offered to NMA Employers bidding on similar work.
logical_representation: IF union_local (Unsupported) PROVIDES_ENABLEMENT_TO(any_employer) -> EXTEND_ENABLEMENT_TO(NMA_Employers) FOR work_package_similarity (llm) == true
reasoning: This is a 'most favored nation' clause that affects wage rates and benefits, ensuring competitive fairness. It's a rule about how wage rates are determined.

name: Implementation Timeline for Monetary Changes
rule_text: Upon renewal of a Local Reference Agreement the Employer will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notification to implement any initial monetary changes.
summary: After a Local Reference Agreement is renewed, the employer has 30 days from being notified to implement any initial changes to wages or benefits.
logical_representation: UPON agreement_renewal_notification_date (llm) -> IMPLEMENT_MONETARY_CHANGES(WITHIN_30_DAYS)
reasoning: This rule governs the timing for applying new wage rates, a procedural aspect of wage administration.

name: Final Pay on Termination at Jobsite
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or terminated from the services of the Company shall normally receive their final wages, vacation pay due, and unemployment insurance record of earnings before they leave the jobsite.
summary: Typically, when an employee is laid off or terminated, they should receive all final pay and their ROE before leaving the jobsite.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] -> PAY(FINAL_WAGES) AND PROVIDE(ROE) BEFORE event (Unsupported) == 'LEAVING_JOBSITE'
reasoning: This rule sets the standard procedure and timing for the final payment of wages upon cessation of employment.

name: Exception for Final Pay and ROE Delivery
rule_text: It is recognized that there will be certain occasions when the above procedure is not possible. In these cases final wages, vacation pay due, and Records of Earnings (ROE's) will be mailed to the employee's last  recorded  home  address  within  three  (3)  working  days  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory  Holidays.
summary: If final pay and ROE cannot be issued at the jobsite upon termination, they must be mailed to the employee's last known address within three business days.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND payment_method (llm) == 'MAIL_FINAL_PAY' -> SEND(WITHIN_3_BUSINESS_DAYS)
reasoning: This provides an alternative timeline and method for final wage payment, a key part of the wage process.

name: ROE Delivery Options on Termination
rule_text: EI  Records  of  Earnings  (ROE's)  will  be  filed  electronically  or  at  the  employees' written request be mailed Express Post to the employees' last recorded home address within three (3) working days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: Records of Earnings will be filed electronically unless the employee makes a written request for it to be sent by Express Post, both within three business days of termination.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND employee_request (llm) != 'MAIL_ROE' -> FILE_ROE_ELECTRONICALLY(WITHIN_3_BUSINESS_DAYS) ELSE MAIL_ROE(WITHIN_3_BUSINESS_DAYS)
reasoning: This rule specifies the process and timeline for providing the Record of Earnings, a document essential for employment insurance which is tied to wages earned.

name: Final Pay Timeline for Electronic Deposits
rule_text: When electronic deposits are made, the final deposit and other termination document mailings/filings must be made by the next pay period.
summary: For employees paid by electronic deposit, their final pay and documents must be processed by the next regular payday.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND payment_method (llm) == 'ELECTRONIC_DEPOSIT' -> PROCESS_FINAL_PAYMENT(BY_NEXT_PAY_PERIOD)
reasoning: This sets the deadline for final wage payment specifically for employees using direct deposit.

name: Penalty for Late Mailed Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay earnings not be mailed within this time period noted above, the  Company  will  pay  a  penalty  of  $100.00  per  day,  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory Holidays, until the mailing or filing is made.
summary: If the company fails to mail final pay within the required three business days, it must pay a penalty of $100 for each business day the payment is late.
logical_representation: IF payment_method (llm) == 'MAIL_FINAL_PAY' AND NOT SENT(WITHIN_3_BUSINESS_DAYS) -> PENALTY($100_PER_DAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a financial penalty for failing to adhere to the wage payment timeline, enforcing the payment rules.

name: Penalty for Late Electronic Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay not be electronically submitted by the next pay period the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays. The penalty will be imposed from the pay date for which the electronic deposit was not received.
summary: If the company fails to make the final electronic deposit by the next pay period, it must pay a penalty of $100 for each business day of delay, starting from the missed payday.
logical_representation: IF payment_method (llm) == 'ELECTRONIC_DEPOSIT' AND NOT PAID(BY_NEXT_PAY_PERIOD) -> PENALTY($100_PER_DAY)
reasoning: This is a financial penalty tied to the failure to meet the electronic final wage payment deadline.

name: Correction Period for Final Pay Error (Electronic)
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the final electronic deposit, the Company will have three (3) days, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment.
summary: If there is a miscalculation on a final electronic pay deposit, the company has three days after being notified to issue a correction payment.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'MISCALCULATION' AND payment_type (llm) == 'FINAL_ELECTRONIC' -> CORRECT_PAYMENT(WITHIN_3_DAYS_OF_NOTIFICATION)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific timeframe for correcting wage calculation errors, a key part of ensuring accurate pay.

name: Penalty for Late Correction of Final Pay Error
rule_text: Should this make-up payment not be made within the three (3) days, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 from the pay date of the final electronic deposit.
summary: If the company fails to make the correction payment for a final pay error within the allotted three days, it must pay a $100 penalty.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'MISCALCULATION' AND payment_type (llm) == 'FINAL_ELECTRONIC' AND NOT CORRECTED(WITHIN_3_DAYS) -> PENALTY($100)
reasoning: This rule attaches a financial penalty to the failure to correct a wage payment error in a timely manner.

name: Grievance Timeline for Final Pay Issues
rule_text: Complaints/grievances with respect to non-receipt of final wages, vacation pay due and employment insurance record of earnings must be raised to the Company in a timely fashion, in any event, not more than ten (10) days, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Holidays, from date of lay-off/termination.
summary: Any complaints or grievances regarding the non-receipt of final pay or ROE must be submitted to the company within ten business days of the layoff or termination date.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'FINAL_PAY_GRIEVANCE' -> SUBMIT(WITHIN_10_BUSINESS_DAYS_OF_TERMINATION)
reasoning: This is a procedural rule defining the time limit for formally disputing final wage payments.

name: Correction of Major Weekly Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should employees be short paid ten (10) or more hours or equivalent value on their weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit, the Company will provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays after notification of the shortage is received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If an employee is short-paid by 10 or more hours on their weekly pay, the company must issue a correction payment within ten business days of receiving written notification.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) >= 10 -> CORRECT_PAYMENT(WITHIN_10_BUSINESS_DAYS_OF_NOTIFICATION)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific procedure and timeline for correcting significant wage payment errors.

name: Penalty for Late Correction of Major Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Company will pay the penalty amount noted in article 9.400 above from the date the issue was raised by the employee and received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If the company fails to correct a major pay shortage (10+ hours) within the ten-day timeframe, it must pay a $100 daily penalty starting from the date of notification.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) >= 10 AND NOT CORRECTED(WITHIN_10_BUSINESS_DAYS) -> PENALTY($100_PER_DAY)
reasoning: This rule imposes a financial penalty for failing to rectify a significant payroll error promptly.

name: Correction of Minor Weekly Pay Shortage
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit where an employee is short paid less than ten (10) hours or equivalent, the Company will have two (2) payroll periods, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment.
summary: If an employee is short-paid by less than 10 hours, the company has two pay periods after being notified to make the correction.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) < 10 -> CORRECT_PAYMENT(WITHIN_2_PAY_PERIODS_OF_NOTIFICATION)
reasoning: This rule provides a distinct, more lenient timeline for correcting smaller payroll errors.

name: Penalty for Late Correction of Minor Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this make-up payment not be made within the two (2) payroll periods, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day from the date the Company was notified.
summary: If the company fails to correct a minor pay shortage (less than 10 hours) within two pay periods, it must pay a penalty of $100 per day, starting from the date of notification.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) < 10 AND NOT CORRECTED(WITHIN_2_PAY_PERIODS) -> PENALTY($100_PER_DAY)
reasoning: A financial penalty is established for failing to correct even minor payroll errors within the specified timeframe.

name: Late Query Impact on Minor Shortage Penalty
rule_text: Should  the  employee  not  submit  a  payroll  query  within  three  (3)  weeks  of  the  payroll  error (miscalculation) the penalty payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day will be applicable on day 15 from the submission of the query.
summary: If an employee waits more than three weeks to report a minor pay shortage, the daily penalty for non-correction by the company will only start on the 15th day after the query was submitted.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) < 10 AND query_submission_delay_weeks (llm) > 3 -> PENALTY_START_DATE(DAY_15_AFTER_QUERY)
reasoning: This rule modifies the penalty conditions for payroll errors based on the employee's timeliness in reporting the issue.

name: Overpayment Negotiation
rule_text: When the Company or the Employee becomes aware of an overpayment, the Company the Union and the Employee will meet to negotiate the repayment terms.
summary: If an employee is overpaid, the company, the union, and the employee must meet to negotiate a repayment plan.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'OVERPAYMENT' -> NEGOTIATE_REPAYMENT(COMPANY, UNION, EMPLOYEE)
reasoning: This rule establishes the required process for resolving wage overpayments, which is the inverse of a shortage and part of correct wage administration.

name: Daily Travel: Company-Supplied Transportation
rule_text: On those projects that are located between forty-five (45) radius kilometers to one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from Edmonton and/or Calgary City Hall(s) or other Hiring Hall locations, the Company shall supply suitable transportation to and from the project and mutually agreed to pick-up points.
summary: For projects located between 45 and 120 radius kilometers from a City Hall or Hiring Hall, the company must provide transportation to and from the job site via agreed-upon pickup points.
logical_representation: IF (project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120) OR (project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) <= 120) -> PROVIDE(transportation)
reasoning: This rule outlines a travel benefit (transportation) based on project distance, which is a component of subsistence and remote work allowances.

name: Daily Travel: Vehicle Allowance Alternative
rule_text: Alternatively, the Company shall pay to each employee a vehicle allowance at the rate established by the Canadian Revenue Agency per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone to the project and return.
summary: As an alternative to providing transportation for projects 45-120 km away, the company can pay a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate. This is calculated per kilometer from the 45 km free zone boundary to the project and back, for each day worked or reported.
logical_representation: IF ((project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120) OR (project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) <= 120)) AND transportation_not_provided (llm) == true -> ALLOWANCE(CRA_rate_per_km_from_45km_zone_and_return)
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary allowance for travel, which is a form of subsistence entitlement.

name: Subsistence Rate Updates
rule_text: Subsistence amounts to be cross referenced with any changes made through the CLRA and these amounts will be updated within the Agreement in a timely manner.
summary: Subsistence payment amounts must be checked against and updated to match any changes made by the CLRA.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(subsistence_amounts_must_align_with_CLRA_changes)
reasoning: This rule governs the value and source of subsistence amounts, directly relating it to the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Subsistence or Camp Eligibility
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid or camp provided on projects which are more than one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: For projects located more than 120 radius kilometers from a City Hall or Hiring Hall, the company must either pay a subsistence allowance or provide camp accommodation.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 120 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 120 -> ALLOWANCE(subsistence) OR PROVIDE(camp)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary condition (distance) for eligibility for either a subsistence allowance or camp, which is central to the topic.

name: Standard Subsistence Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The standard daily subsistence rate is $150.00, paid for each day an employee works or reports for work.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status (Unsupported) IN ['worked', 'reported_for'] AND no_specific_location_rate_applies (llm) == true -> ALLOWANCE(150.00)

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Sites
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 radius kilometers or more from the reference point, subsistence allowance is paid for all seven days of the week.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 475 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) >= 475 -> PAY(subsistence_7_days_per_week)
reasoning: This rule modifies the payment frequency of the subsistence allowance based on project distance, directly relating to that topic.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture Waiver
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: If an employee is absent, the loss of their subsistence allowance for that day can be excused if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == true -> CONSTRAINT(waive_subsistence_forfeiture)
reasoning: This rule describes a condition under which the forfeiture of a subsistence allowance can be avoided, making it part of that topic.

name: Additional Subsistence for Travel Day
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations. This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (i.e. receipt or registration verification).
summary: Non-local employees on subsistence projects over 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence to cover travel. This applies to either the day before starting or the day after finishing, provided they show proof of accommodation like a receipt.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == false AND (project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 200 OR project_distance_from_hiring_hall (Unsupported) > 200) AND claim_type (Unsupported) == 'accommodation_receipt_provided' -> ALLOWANCE(1_additional_day_subsistence)
reasoning: This rule provides an additional subsistence payment under specific travel and residency conditions, clearly placing it in the subsistence category.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Allowance with Client Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no travel allowance will be paid.
logical_representation: IF client_provided_transportation (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition under which a travel allowance is forfeited, directly relating it to the subsistence and travel topic.

name: Travel Allowance Review
rule_text: Initial and terminal travel amounts will be reviewed by the National Maintenance Council should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The amounts for initial and terminal travel will be reviewed by the National Maintenance Council if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(initial_terminal_travel_amounts_reviewed_by_National_Maintenance_Council)
reasoning: This is a procedural rule about how travel allowances are maintained, directly relating it to the subsistence topic.

name: Initial Travel Allowance Payment Timing
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay-off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid out to an employee after they have been on the job for 15 calendar days, or when they are laid off, whichever comes first.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job (llm) >= 15 OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(initial_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule governs the timing of a travel allowance payment, which is an administrative aspect of the subsistence allowance topic.

name: Terminal Travel Allowance Payment Timing
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The terminal travel allowance is paid to an employee when they are laid off.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(terminal_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule governs the timing of a travel allowance payment, which is an administrative aspect of the subsistence allowance topic.

name: Travel Allowance Forfeiture on Quit or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before they become eligible for the initial or terminal travel payment, they forfeit any outstanding travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED_FOR_CAUSE'] -> FORFEIT(outstanding_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule details conditions for forfeiting a travel allowance, which is a key part of the subsistence allowance rules.

name: Local Resident Entitlements on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 14.100 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: On a subsistence project, local residents are not eligible for the accommodation allowance or initial/terminal travel. However, if they live more than 45 radius kilometers from the project site, they will receive a daily travel payment.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true -> FORFEIT(subsistence) AND FORFEIT(initial_terminal_travel) AND IF residence_distance_from_project_km (llm) > 45 -> PAY(daily_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific allowances available to local residents, distinguishing them from non-locals, which is a common feature of subsistence policies.

name: Transportation for Non-Local Employees on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid a vehicle allowance at the rate established by the Canadian Revenue Agency.
summary: On subsistence projects, employees living more than 45 radius kilometers from the job site will either be given transportation or paid a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == false AND residence_distance_from_project_km (llm) > 45 -> PROVIDE(transportation) OR ALLOWANCE(CRA_vehicle_allowance)
reasoning: This rule specifies travel benefits for non-local employees on a subsistence job, making it a subsistence-related rule.

name: Daily Travel Forfeiture for Choosing Subsistence over Camp
rule_text: Employees who are offered camp accommodation and choose to receive subsistence instead are not entitled to daily travel outside of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job.
summary: If an employee is offered camp accommodation but chooses to take the subsistence allowance instead, they forfeit their right to receive daily travel pay for commuting from outside the 45 km zone.
logical_representation: IF camp_accommodation_offered (llm) == true AND employee_choice (llm) == 'subsistence' -> FORFEIT(daily_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule describes a trade-off between different types of subsistence benefits (camp vs. cash) and its effect on another allowance (travel), which is central to the topic.

name: Transportation for Ft. McMurray Workers
rule_text: Ft. McMurray residents or those employees accommodated in Ft. McMurray will be provided with transportation to and from the jobsite by the Employer.
summary: For jobs in the Ft. McMurray area, the Employer must provide transportation to and from the jobsite for employees who are residents of or are being accommodated in Ft. McMurray.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'Ft. McMurray' AND (is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true OR is_accommodated_in_Ft_McMurray (llm) == true) -> PROVIDE(transportation)
reasoning: This rule provides a location-specific transportation benefit, which is a form of subsistence support.

name: Allowances for Travel from Edmonton to Ft. McMurray
rule_text: Employees travelling to Ft. McMurray from Edmonton will be paid initial and terminal travel pursuant to Article 14.100 b) and provided with camp accommodation or accommodation allowance.
summary: Employees who travel from Edmonton to work in Ft. McMurray are entitled to receive initial and terminal travel pay, and will also be provided with either camp accommodation or a subsistence allowance.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'Ft. McMurray' AND travel_origin (llm) == 'Edmonton' -> PAY(initial_terminal_travel) AND (PROVIDE(camp) OR ALLOWANCE(subsistence))
reasoning: This rule combines multiple travel and accommodation allowances for a specific travel route, making it a clear subsistence-related rule.

name: Staggered Start Times
rule_text: Start times may be staggered two (2) hours between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. as job conditions warrant.
summary: Depending on job conditions, start times can be staggered by two hours, anywhere between 7:00 AM and 9:00 AM.
logical_representation: IF job_conditions (llm) == 'warranted' -> ALLOW(staggered_start_time BETWEEN '07:00' AND '09:00')
reasoning: This rule provides flexibility in defining the start of the workday, which affects how daily hours and potential overtime are calculated.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Straight Time Day
rule_text: On a straight time, day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes paid at the time and one-half rate.
summary: If an employee is unable to take their break on a regular straight-time day, they must be paid an extra 30 minutes at the time-and-a-half rate.
logical_representation: IF is_missed_break (llm) == true AND is_overtime_day (llm) == false -> PAY(30_minutes * 1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies a penalty payment for a missed entitlement. Since the penalty is calculated as additional paid time at a premium rate, it falls under the categorization and calculation of worked time.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Overtime Day
rule_text: On an overtime day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If an employee misses their break on an overtime day, they must be paid an extra 30 minutes at the overtime rate that applies to that day.
logical_representation: IF is_missed_break (llm) == true AND is_overtime_day (llm) == true -> PAY(30_minutes * applicable_overtime_rate)
reasoning: Similar to the straight-time penalty, this rule defines a payment based on missed break time, calculated at a premium rate. This is directly related to labor time calculation.

name: Staggering Paid Breaks
rule_text: Under schedules utilizing a half (½) hour (paid break) system, they may be staggered one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies.
summary: Paid 30-minute breaks can be moved up to one hour earlier or later to accommodate production or emergencies.
logical_representation: IF has_paid_breaks (llm) == true -> ALLOW(stagger_break_time MAX 1_hour)
reasoning: This rule governs the timing and flexibility of breaks within the workday, which is an aspect of managing and defining the structure of worked time.

name: Penalty for Excessive Break Staggering
rule_text: The above penalty clauses outlined in 15.100(i) a) and b) will apply in instances when the staggered one half (½) hour (paid break) is moved greater than one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies.
summary: If a paid 30-minute break is moved by more than one hour, it is considered a missed break, and the corresponding penalty payments apply.
logical_representation: IF break_stagger_duration (llm) > 1_hour -> SET(is_missed_break (llm) = true)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition that triggers a penalty payment. Since the penalty is paid time at a premium rate, it is classified under the rules governing labor worked time.

name: Unpaid Lunch Break
rule_text: The mid-shift lunch break will be of one half (1/2) hour in duration and will be unpaid.
summary: There is a 30-minute unpaid lunch break in the middle of the shift.
logical_representation: PROVIDE(30_min_unpaid_lunch_break)
reasoning: This rule defines a period within the workday that is not paid. It's essential for correctly calculating the total paid hours and thus falls under worked time rules.

name: Shift Change Notice Penalty
rule_text: Where employees are requested to take a shift change, as much notice as possible will be given. If eight (8) hours notice is not provided then all regular hours worked on the first shift on the new schedule will be paid at time and one-half the straight time total package rate (1-1/2).
summary: If an employee's shift is changed with less than 8 hours' notice, all regular hours on the first new shift must be paid at time-and-a-half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice_hours (llm) < 8 -> PAY(first_shift_regular_hours * 1.5)
reasoning: This rule imposes a premium pay rate on regular hours under specific circumstances (short notice shift change). This directly alters how worked time is paid, making it a labor time rule.

name: Meal Allowance In Lieu of Meal, Scheduled Overtime
rule_text: Scheduled Overtime: 1) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and 2) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If it's impractical to provide a meal during scheduled overtime, the employee receives 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time rate plus a 15-minute paid rest break at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF is_scheduled_overtime (llm) == true AND meal_entitlement_triggered == true AND is_meal_provided (llm) == false -> PAY(30_minutes*ST) AND PROVIDE(15_min_paid_rest_break)
reasoning: This rule specifies the monetary and paid-time compensation provided when a meal entitlement is met but a physical meal cannot be given. This is a core rule for meal allowances.

name: Meal Allowance In Lieu of Meal, Unscheduled Overtime
rule_text: Unscheduled Overtime: 1) a payment of forty dollars ($40.00) as a meal allowance. 2) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and 3) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay
summary: If it's impractical to provide a meal during unscheduled overtime, the employee receives a $40 meal allowance, 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time rate, and a 15-minute paid rest break.
logical_representation: IF is_scheduled_overtime (llm) == false AND meal_entitlement_triggered == true AND is_meal_provided (llm) == false -> ALLOWANCE($40) AND PAY(30_minutes*ST) AND PROVIDE(15_min_paid_rest_break)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific monetary allowance and other compensation for a missed meal during unscheduled overtime, making it a key LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE rule.

name: Meal Allowance and Subsistence
rule_text: There shall be no meal allowance applicable to those receiving subsistence, however any reduction to the current subsistence rates will attract a meal allowance payment equivalent to the reduction.
summary: Employees receiving a subsistence allowance are not eligible for an overtime meal allowance, unless their subsistence rate is reduced, in which case they get a meal allowance equal to the reduction amount.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_subsistence (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(meal_allowance) UNLESS subsistence_rate_reduced == true
reasoning: The primary topic is LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE because the rule's main purpose is to disqualify employees from receiving it. It has a secondary link to LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE as that is the condition for disqualification.

name: Meal Allowance in Camp
rule_text: Where a camp is provided, employees will not receive the forty dollars ($40.00) meal allowance where they are able to receive a camp meal at the end of their shift.
summary: If an employee is staying in a camp and can get a meal there after their shift, they are not eligible for the $40 overtime meal allowance.
logical_representation: IF is_in_camp (llm) == true AND is_camp_meal_available (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(meal_allowance_$40)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition (staying in a camp with meals) that disqualifies an employee from receiving a specific meal allowance, making it a rule under that topic.

name: Rest Period Requirement
rule_text: It is not intended that an employee shall work more than sixteen (16) hours in any given twenty-four (24) hour period therefore it is established that the employee must have eight (8) continuous hours off between regular shifts or they will be paid overtime rates for all hours worked in excess of the first eight (8) until such times as they have eight (8) continuous hours off.
summary: An employee should not work more than 16 hours in a 24-hour period and must have at least 8 consecutive hours off between shifts. If they don't get the 8-hour break, all hours worked on the next shift are paid at overtime rates until the break is taken.
logical_representation: IF hours_since_last_shift (llm) < 8 -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, OT) UNTIL hours_since_last_shift (llm) >= 8
reasoning: This rule imposes a premium pay rate (overtime) as a penalty for not providing a sufficient rest period. This directly impacts how hours are paid, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: No Loss of Pay for Rest Period
rule_text: It is the intent of this clause that no employee shall lose pay on a normal shift due to taking the required eight (8) hour break rule.
summary: An employee will not lose pay from their normal shift if its start time is pushed back to ensure they receive their required 8-hour rest period.
logical_representation: IF hours_since_last_shift (llm) < 8 AND next_shift_start_delayed == true -> PAY(normal_shift_pay, GUARANTEED)
reasoning: This rule guarantees pay under specific circumstances related to scheduling and rest periods, ensuring the employee's regular earnings are protected. It is a rule about how time and pay are administered.

name: Employer Online Orientation & Onboarding Pay
rule_text: If an employer requires an employee to complete online orientation and on-boarding, where applicable, the Employer shall estimate a reasonable amount of time to complete the online orientation and on-boarding where applicable. The Employer shall pay an allowance for completing the course(s) equal to that time estimate, to a maximum of eight (8) hours, at the straight time total package hourly rate.
summary: Employees required to complete employer-mandated online orientation and onboarding will be paid for the estimated time to complete it, up to a maximum of 8 hours, at their straight-time total package hourly rate.
logical_representation: IF activity_type (Unsupported) == 'EMPLOYER_ONBOARDING' -> PAY(estimated_time_hours * straight_time_total_package_rate) WITH MAX_HOURS(8)
reasoning: The rule defines compensation for time spent on a required work-related activity, which is a form of worked time.

name: Client Online Orientation & Onboarding Pay
rule_text: Employees will be compensated for the prescribed amount of time, at the straight time total package hourly rate, for completing any Owner / Client online orientation, onboarding or basic training courses required of an employee.
summary: Employees are paid for the time it takes to complete required client or owner online orientation, onboarding, or basic training. The pay is at the straight-time total package hourly rate for the prescribed duration of the course.
